questions.question: Receptor
questions.answer: A component of a biologic system to which a drug binds to bring about a change in function of the system

questions.question: Inert binding site
questions.answer: A component of a biologic system to which a drug binds without changing any function

questions.question: Receptor site
questions.answer: A specific region of a receptor molecule at which the drug binds

questions.question: Agonist
questions.answer: A drug that binds and activates its receptor

questions.question: Partial agonist
questions.answer: A drug that binds to its receptor but produces a smaller effect than a full agonist

questions.question: Effector
questions.answer: A component of a biologic system that brings about the biologic effect after being activated by a receptor; often an ion channel or enzyme

questions.question: Pharmacological antagonist
questions.answer: A drug that binds to its receptor without activating it

questions.question: Competitive antagonist
questions.answer: A pharmacologic antagonist whose effect can be overcome by increasing the dose of agonist

questions.question: Physiologic antagonist
questions.answer: A drug that counters the effects of another by binding to a different receptor and causing opposing effects

questions.question: Chemical antagonist
questions.answer: A drug that counters the effects of another by binding the drug and preventing its action

questions.question: Graded dose-response curve
questions.answer: A graph of the increasing responses to increasing doses of a drug

questions.question: Quantal dose-response curve
questions.answer: A graph of the fraction of a population that shows a specified response to increasing doses of a drug

questions.question: Efficacy
questions.answer: The maximum effect of drug can bring about, regardless of dose

questions.question: Potency
questions.answer: The dose or concentration require to bring about 50% of a drugâ€™s maximum effect
